Ammonia saturation concentration changes little with vacuum in the absolute pressure range of 20.0–101.3 kPa (Whitfield, 1974; Salavera et al., 2005). (1) d C / d t = − K L a ( C − C s ) (2) α N H 3 = 1 / ( 1 + 10 p K a s − p H ) (3) p K a , T s = p K a , 298 s +( 298 − T ) (4) p K a , P s = p K a , 1 s +P / T where dC/dt = rate of ammonia mass transfer, mg/L/h; K L  = overall liquid-phase mass transfer coefficient, m/h; C s = saturation concentration of free ammonia in liquid, mg/L; C = concentration of free ammonia in liquid, mg/L; a = area-volume ratio of the liquid, 1/m;  α N H 3  = fraction of free ammonia in total ammonia;  K a s  = the stoichiometric acid hydrolysis constant of ammonium;  p K a , T s ,  p K a , 298 s ,  p K a , P s , and  p K a , 1 s  = the negative logarithm of  K a s at temperature T, 298 (K), pressure P (atm), and 1 atm, respectively. The first objective of this study was to develop boiling point temperature-vacuum curves and investigate how ammonia mass transfer is affected by boiling point temperature and vacuum combinations. To the best of our knowledge, ammonia mass transfer kinetic constants (K L and C s ) have not been reported previously for digestate or wastewater at a reduced pressure as in vacuum thermal stripping. The kinetic constants provide essential data for design and feasibility study of this novel process.
